abstract.text: The COVID-19 pandemic has redefined 'essential care', and reproductive healthcare has become a 36 frequently targeted and debated topic. As Obstetricians and Gynecologists (OBGYN), we stand with our 37 patients and others as advocates for women's reproductive health. With the medical and surgical 38 training to provide all aspects of reproductive healthcare, OBGYNs are indispensable and uniquely 39 positioned to advocate for the full spectrum of care that our patients need right now. All patients have a 40 right to these services. Contraception and abortion care remain essential, and we need to work at the 41 local, state and federal level on policies that preserve these critical services. We must also support 42 policies that will promote expansion of care, including lengthening Medicaid pregnancy/postpartum 43 coverage. While we continue to see patients, this is the time to engage outside clinical encounters by 44 participating in lobbying and other advocacy efforts to preserve essential services, protecting the health, 45 life, and welfare of our patients during COVID-19. 46 47

Due to the massive strain placed on the 52 healthcare system, a critical need exists to preserve resources. Varying restrictions are appropriately in 53 place, limiting medical care based on regional disease impact and by recommendations from bodies 54 such as The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG). 1 "Essential" and "elective" are 55 the terms used to determine what procedures are preserved. By categorizing time-sensitive 56 reproductive health procedures (i.e. abortion), as "non-essential", several states have limited women's 57 reproductive health choices. The status of other procedures, such as sterilization and long-acting 58 reversible contraception (LARC) insertions or removals, have been debated and restricted during the 59 crisis. Regrettably, if Medicaid coverage lapses or Title XIX consent forms expire during the pandemic, many 107 women will lose their opportunity to obtain a desired sterilization procedure. Fortunately, the Centers 108 for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has announced the suspension of all reverification during the 109 COVID-19 crisis, and coverage will continue for now. 6 We must advocate for expedited access to all 110 contraceptive options. When a patient is unable to receive a desired method due to necessary COVID-19 111 restrictions, providers need to educate and counsel about alternate contraceptive methods to prevent 112 this pandemic from leading to more short-interval, and potentially undesired, pregnancies.
